instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used in the detection of the enzymatic concentration and activity of the indicators in sheep serum?
Output: Raman spectral can be used in the detection of the enzymatic concentration and activity of the indicators in sheep serum.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were in the detection of the enzymatic concentration and activity of the indicators in sheep serum?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used in the detection of the enzymatic concentration and activity of the indicators in sheep serum included DOSC (Deviation Standardization), airPLS algorithm for baseline correction, and SPA (Successive Projections Algorithm) for feature extraction.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the quantitative effect of the model in determining the enzymatic concentration and activity of the indicators in sheep serum?
Output: The past study proposes conducting deviation standardization (DS) for the determination results of various substances to evaluate the model's performance.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the development of the quantitative model for monitoring the concentration/enzymatic activity of indicators in sheep serum using Raman spectroscopy combined with DOSC-SPA-PLSR-DS optimization?
Output: The machine learning models used in the development of the quantitative model for monitoring the concentration/enzymatic activity of indicators in sheep serum using Raman spectroscopy combined with DOSC-SPA-PLSR-DS optimization are partial least square regression (PLSR), support vector regression based on genetic algorithm optimization (GA-SVR), and extreme learning machine (ELM) models.

instruction: Can the optimized DOSC-SPA-PLSR-DS quantitative model using sheep serum Raman spectroscopy be considered superior to traditional methods in monitoring the concentration/enzymatic activity of indicators in real time?
Output: Yes, the optimized DOSC-SPA-PLSR-DS quantitative model using sheep serum Raman spectroscopy can be considered superior to traditional methods in monitoring the concentration/enzymatic activity of indicators in real time. The research results showed that this model had better determination results for 101 sheep serum samples, with improved accuracy and reduced running time compared to traditional methods. This indicates that the optimized model can efficiently monitor the concentration/enzymatic activity of indicators in real time, providing a new strategy for intelligent supervision of animal husbandry.
